property.name: text
property.value: Authors: Jie Liu, Haiyang Zheng, and Edward A. Lee

property.name: text
property.value: Right click to look inside the "Masses" actor to see the modal behavior.

property.name: text
property.value: This model shows a hybrid system, which mixes continuous-time modeling with finite state machines. In this example, two point masses on springs oscillate. They occasionally collide, in which case, they stick together and oscillate together. The stickiness decays, and they eventually come apart again. This is an example of a modal model, where there are two modes, "together" and "separate". Each mode is modeled by a state in an FSM, and each state refines to a continuous-time model of the dynamics in that mode.

property.name: text
property.value: This example requires Java3D. If you do not have it installed, you can get it from: http://java.sun.com/products/java-media/3D/

property.name: text
property.value:
The sticky masses system has two modes of operation, "Separate" and "Together," corresponding to whether the point masses are stuck together. The transition from init to Separate initializes the positions and velocities. The transition from Separate to Together is taken when the positions are equal and the velocity of the left mass is greater than the velocity of the right mass. The transition from Together to Separate is taken when the stickiness can no longer overcome the force of the springs.
Look inside the states to see the dynamics in each mode.

property.name: setActions
setActions
text
property.value: In this mode, the masses are not touching, so their dynamics are given by seperate 2nd order differential equations. There is no stickiness, and the differential force on the masses is not useful in this mode, so those outputs are simply absent.

property.name: text
property.value: The difference of spring forces applied on the masses.

property.name: text
property.value: In this mode, the masses are stuck together, so their accelerations, velocities, and positions are all identical. The stickiness decays exponentially according to a first-order differential equation represented at the left.
